title: 113_hr2455
content:
The "Nevada Native Nations Land Act" includes provisions for the conveyance of land to Elko County for motocross use and the conveyance of land to certain Indian tribes to be held in trust. The Act defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. TITLE I--ELKO MOTOCROSS LAND CONVEYANCE

SEC. 101. DEFINITIONS.
- City: Elko, Nevada
- County: Elko, Nevada
- Map: "Elko Motocross Park" dated January 9, 2010

SEC. 102. CONVEYANCE OF LAND TO COUNTY. The Secretary will convey approximately 275 acres of land to Elko County, Nevada, managed by the Bureau of Land Management as "Elko Motocross Park". The legal description of the parcel will be finalized by the Secretary. The Secretary may correct minor errors in the map or legal description, which will be available for public inspection. The conveyed land can only be used for motocross, bicycle, off-highway vehicle, or stock car racing, or other public purposes allowed under the Recreation and Public Purposes Act. The county is responsible for survey and administrative costs for transferring title to the land. If the land conveyed under this section is no longer used for a public purpose, it may revert to the United States. Title II involves the conveyance of land to Indian tribes to be held in trust. If the land is no longer used for a public purpose, it may revert to the United States. Title II involves the conveyance of land to Indian tribes to be held in trust. The Te-Moak Tribe of Western Shoshone Indians of Nevada (Elko Band) will have land conveyed to them, described in a specific map, to be held in trust by the United States for their benefit and become part of their reservation. Title II involves the conveyance of land to Indian tribes to be held in trust. The approximately 373 acres of land administered by the Bureau of Land Management will be held in trust for the Fort McDermitt Paiute and Shoshone Tribe, as depicted on the map entitled "Fort McDermitt Indian Reservation Expansion Act". The Fort McDermitt Paiute and Shoshone Tribe will have approximately 19,094 acres of land held in trust by the United States as part of their reservation. The land is administered by the Bureau of Land Management and depicted on the map as "Reservation Expansion Lands". Additionally, the Mountain City Administrative Site Proposed Acquisition map dated July 29, 2013, will be used for the conveyance of land to be held in trust for the Shoshone Paiute Tribes. The United States will convey approximately 82 acres of land to be held in trust for the Shoshone Paiute Tribes of the Duck Valley Indian Reservation. The land is currently administered by the Forest Service and will become part of the reservation. The Summit Lake Paiute Tribe will receive approximately 941 acres of land held in trust by the United States, as depicted on a specific map. This land will become part of the tribe's reservation. The Bureau of Land Management will transfer land to be held in trust for the Reno-Sparks Indian Colony as part of their reservation expansion. The map detailing this transfer is available for public inspection. The Bureau of Land Management will transfer approximately 13,434 acres of land to be held in trust for the Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe as depicted on the map titled "Pyramid Lake Indian Reservation Expansion". The Bureau of Land Management will transfer approximately 13,434 acres of land to the Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe to be held in trust. This land, approximately 11,719 acres, will be part of the tribe's reservation as depicted on the map as "Reservation Expansion Lands". SEC. 202. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary must survey boundary lines to establish land boundaries for Indian tribes under section 201. Land taken into trust is not eligible for gaming and can be used for fuel reduction and landscape restoration activities beneficial to the tribe. The land taken into trust can be used for fuel reduction and landscape restoration activities beneficial to the Indian tribe and the Bureau of Land Management. The House of Representatives passed the bill on December 1, 2014. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
